newsitem.title: USA: Mercury says renews $50-mln credit line.
newsitem.headline: Mercury says renews $50-mln credit line.

text.p: Mercury Finance Co said Thursday its creditors granted waivers allowing a 90-day extension of its $50 million line of credit with BankAmerica Corp's Bank of America.
The waivers permit Mercury to continue to pledge assets as collateral on the $50 million credit facility. The previous waiver period had only been for 30 days, Mercury said.
"The waivers and the term of the loan now extend out to June 10, 1997," said the sub-prime auto lender.
"This 90-day extension is a tangible demonstration of confidence in Mercury," said chief executive William Brandt.
"The expanded waiver period gives the company breathing room to focus on operations and on the exploration of long term financing alternatives," he said.

Under the terms of the waivers, during the 90-day period, the company will resume interest payments on nearly all of its roughly $1 billion in debt and will pay any interest that is now past due, Mercury said.
"The company is continuing discussions with the holders of $22 million of subordinated debt regarding the status of their interest payments," the company said.

Mercury received the $50 million in short term financing from Bank of America a month ago. The financing is being used to meet daily operating expenses and interest payments as Mercury confronts numerous difficulties.

The company faces a federal investigation, several shareholder lawsuits, restatement of financial results due to accounting irregularities, and a loss of more than $2 billion in market capitalization after a plunge in its stock price.
The share price fell in January -- after the news of the earnings restatement -- from $14 to less than $2 per share. It closed Wednesday at $2-5/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.
